title: 110_hr1727
content:
The Act is titled the "Christopher and Dana Reeve Paralysis Act" and includes sections on paralysis research, rehabilitation research and care, and improving quality of life for persons with paralysis and other physical disabilities. The "Christopher and Dana Reeve Paralysis Act" includes a section on paralysis research conducted by the National Institutes of Health. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may coordinate paralysis research activities to avoid duplication. Grants can be awarded for establishing Christopher and Dana Reeve Paralysis Research Consortia. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may coordinate paralysis research activities to avoid duplication by awarding grants for establishing Christopher and Dana Reeve Paralysis Research Consortia. These consortia can conduct basic, translational, and clinical research on advancing treatments and therapies for various forms of paralysis resulting from central nervous system trauma or stroke. They also facilitate the dissemination of scientific findings and replicate research for scientific and translational purposes. The Director of the National Institutes of Health may coordinate paralysis research activities through Christopher and Dana Reeve Paralysis Research Consortia. These consortia can conduct research on treatments for paralysis from CNS trauma or stroke. The Director may also establish a mechanism for public input on NIH programs related to paralysis research. TITLE II--PARALYSIS REHABILITATION RESEARCH AND CARE

Activities of the National Institutes of Health focus on research to enhance daily function for individuals with paralysis. The Director may award grants to entities for planning, establishing, and supporting multicenter networks of clinical sites focusing on paralysis rehabilitation research. The networks collaborate to design intervention protocols and outcomes measures for conditions resulting from central nervous system trauma or stroke. The Director may award grants for establishing clinical networks focusing on paralysis rehabilitation research, including assessing efficacy of therapies, developing assistive technology, and understanding body responses to impairments. Coordination of information among networks and reporting activities to the Director is also required. Title III focuses on improving the quality of life for individuals with paralysis and other physical disabilities through various programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may study health challenges related to paralysis and physical disabilities, and implement projects to enhance the quality of life for individuals with these conditions. This includes developing a national action plan in collaboration with voluntary health agencies. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may implement projects to enhance the quality of life for individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities. This includes supporting programs for care, rehabilitation, and dissemination of information, establishing a population-based database for research, and replicating best practices across states. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention develop innovative programs within State-based disability and health programs to support quality of life for individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities. This includes caregiver education, promoting proper nutrition and physical activity, education for healthcare providers, prevention of complications, home- and community-based interventions, and removing barriers to community integration. The Secretary may award grants to State and local health agencies for establishing databases, developing action plans, and fostering partnerships for individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities. The Secretary may award grants to State and local health agencies for establishing databases, developing action plans, and fostering partnerships for individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities. Private health and disability organizations can receive funding for disseminating information to the public and improving access to services for those living with paralysis and other physical disabilities and their caregivers. The Secretary may award grants for establishing databases, developing action plans, and fostering partnerships for individuals with paralysis and physical disabilities. Private organizations can receive funding for disseminating information and improving access to services for those living with disabilities and their caregivers. The Secretary shall coordinate activities under this section across agencies of the Department of Health and Human Services. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2011 for this purpose. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 15, 2007.
